wikipedia_page.main: Andrew Brown  (22 August 1763 – 19 February 1834) was Professor of Rhetoric at Edinburgh University and Moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland in 1813. He was also a historian and author, closely connected to the history of Nova Scotia, having served as a minister at St. Matthew's United Church (Halifax).

In 1808 he left the ministry to become Professor of Logic and Metaphysics at the University of Edinburgh. At that time he lived at 104 Princes Street.Edinburgh Post Office Directory 1810 In 1811 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. His proposers were Dr John Barclay, Thomas Charles Hope, and Rev Andrew Brown. The University of Edinburgh awarded him an honorary doctorate (DD) in 1813.
In 1810 he was elected a fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. His proposers were Alexander Christison, Rev Andrew Brown, and Archibald Alison.
